text:
A general view southward from Duane Street, between Park Row and Centre Street, and showing the City Hall Zone, when it was known as Printing House Square. This view is slightly further westward than No. 1, and also shows Broadway on the farther side of City Hall Park. On the right appears the new Hall of Records (under construction) with the City Hall Building just beyond. Note demolition of the Fire Engine Co. No. 7, Hook and Ladder No. 1, which stood at the northeasterly corner of City Hall Park.

About 1902.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: Manhattan: Duane Street - Park Row

text:
A general view southward from Duane Street, between Park Row (left) and Centre Street (right) and showing in the foreground buildings on the triangular plot that now, (1937) is occupied by the Municipal Building. Shown from left to right are the N. Y. Herald (bearing statue) Brooklyn Bridge Station, Pulitzer (N. Y. World), Staats-Zeitung, N. Y. Times (under renovation), Park Row, United States Post Office, and the City Hall Buildings. The spire shown in the foreground is of St. Andrews R. C. Church which still stands today.

About 1902.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: Manhattan: Duane Street - Park Row

text:
(1) Duane Street, north side, east from but not including Centre Street, to and including City Hall Place. Also shown is City Hall Place, west side, north from Duane Street, to, but not including Pearl Street.
February 24, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2) A view further eastward.
October 22, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Duane Street, north side, east from but not including Centre Street, to and including Cardinal Place; shown in the background is the frame work of the United States Government Building, St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church is in the foreground.
October 8, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, from a different angle. October 8, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same, at an earlier date. The 6-story building on the extreme right is No. 29 and is at the Bowery. Also seen is (left) the rear of a 4-story house and a 2-story adjunct bearing No. 20 City Hall Place, at and adjoining the N.E. corner of Duane Street.
February 24, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

Centre Street, south from and including Duane Street, to and including Park Row, showing the Municipal Building occuping [sic] the east side of this Street.  Shown in the foreground is the southern part of Foley Square, with the Federal Courts Building (under construction) on the left.  The 21 story structure partially shown on the right is the Court Square Building, No. 2 Lafayette Street.

About 1935

Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad, A.R.F.S.
